ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned a lot about DNA & RNA
biotechnology methods, DNA, RNA, regulation, etc
I learned so much about molecular biology and genetic and epigenetic research!
Developed a great understanding of core concepts in molecular biologythe central dogma in great detail and the ways in which it is continually being updated.

I learned how to really glean the key concepts and conclusions from various scientific articles. I learned a LOT about all of the mechanisms in the Central Dogma and how these mechanisms can be altered for disease prevention and treatment.

I learned about the central dogma, and how our understanding of it is rapidly evolving. I also learned about many applications of molecular biology to technology and the frontiers of modern research. I feel excited about all the possibilities we discussed and what the future has in store.
I gained skills in theoretically utilizing scientific methods and knowledge of the central dogma.

I learned the basic mechanisms of how DNA and RNA work, including structure, repair, and other mechanisms in which related machinery function. Then, I was able to learn about applications of molecular biology to therapeutics. I learned critical thinking skills from reading papers and challenged myself to critique them.
Learned a lot about molecular biology and the new technologies that were developed as a result of our better understanding of biological function.
Understanding of the genetic code and research methods on genetics
more in depth knowledge of genetics and biology
I developed a much better understanding for the mechanisms of molecular biology.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Very fast-paced lectures, not super engaging but interesting topics
organized
It was difficult to study for exams because there were no other assignments which covered lecture content, and no other types of practice.

Strengths: Course material was super interesting, teaching team was incredible (both Dr. Pyle and Dr. Isaacs are amazing teachers + the TF's were really nice and supportive)
Weaknesses: There was a lot of content to be covered for the amount of classes that we had, which made it difficult to keep up sometimes

Strengths: the material is really interesting and very currentthe professors do a great job of including recent breakthroughs and ongoing research in the course content. The weekly paper discussions were also fun and engaging, although a few of the papers were dense and difficult. Weaknesses: There is a lot of information coming at you fast through the whole course, and it can sometimes be hard to take it all in.

Strengths: The professors are great lecturers and innovators in their field and it was really interesting learning about their own perspectives on the material. Weaknesses: I felt ill-prepared for the exams since we only went over the research articles in discussion section which were not tested on until the last exam. I also wish the exam was either take-home or shortened, because I and many other students did not have time to finish the exam and go into the detail we were expected to go into with our responses.

Overall, I felt that this course was very well-taught! The lectures were very interesting and informative, and the enthusiasm of the professors set a great tone. The only substantive feedback I have is with regards to the papers we had to read. Reading scientific papers is hard, but I recognize that the only way to get good at it is to do it a lot, so I think having the weekly readings was beneficial. That said, I think the assigned papers varied a bit in quality, so I've included some thoughts on the papers I found most/least helpful (in case having the student perspective is beneficial for making future selections):

Papers I found most helpful:
 "Programmable editing of a target base in genomic DNA without double-stranded DNA cleavage" This was so cool and so well written. I even emailed it to some family members/friends because I thought they might find it interesting!
"Postnatal genome editing partially restores dystrophin expression in a mouse model of muscular dystrophy" Very clearly written and an interesting application of concepts we learned in the course.

Papers that I found less helpful:
"The Long Noncoding RNA Pnky is a Trans-acting Regulator of Cortical Development In Vivo" This paper presented a relatively straight-forward result, but was confusing to read. It probably didn't help that I haven't taken anatomy. I don't think I gained more from reading the paper than I would have if the result were only presented in class.
"Structures of Mismatch Replication Errors Observed in a DNA Polymerase" This paper felt a little all over the place, and I'm not really sure what the takeaway message should be. It wasn't terrible or anything, I just think I'm unlikely to remember it after the course.
Strengths include structured and organized lectures, homework assignments, and exams.

A strength of the course was the content of the material presented. The material was interesting and applicable to other fields. The lectures were pretty organized although it was dense. The discussion of papers was also helpful, including further explanations by my TF with slides. A weakness is the lack of clear feedback on exams or homework. For exams, we could not see what we got wrong unless we went to office hours. For our homework, sometimes the explanation was unclear about why I gave the incorrect answer. Ways to improve perhaps would be to give model answers to the study guides and release our exam comments. Piazza would be helpful to clarify any questions as the lectures are dense. I also wish there would be more time spent on reviewing more difficult material like mechanisms and less time on simpler material.

Strengths - very clear lectures, supportive section to course information, low workload
Weaknesses - hard to tell how you are doing or what is the important information. Does not have study guides or practice exams, and the homework is not directly related to lecture.
The course is relatively engaging and the content is well explained. There could be more comprehensive notes for each lecture and better prep for each exam such as more practice exams
The lectures were excellent, the workload was quite manageable, and the exams were tough but fair.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course adjusted well to the pandemic, although the Canvas exams consistently felt rushed. It was fun to include some of the content specifically about SARS-CoV2

The recorded virtual lectures were engaging and provided numerous examples and applications to understand the material. It was more difficult however remembering 40 slides for each of the seven lectures that the exam tested us on. I did, however, appreciate that the final was not cumulative because it would have actually been impossible to memorize and synthesize that amount of detail. Since a great deal of us depended on the recordings of the lecture, I would have appreciated if we went over the material in discussion section rather than the research articles. Or if there was some kind of enrichment section (like the intro bio sequence has) where the professors could have synthesized the material and we could have gone over the central points.

Having lectures recorded and available for later viewing was really helpful. It made reviewing confusing topics much easier, and was also helpful for exam preparation. Hopefully this continues in the post-Covid era!
Engagement was high during discussion section and professors were able to answer students' questions after class.

The lectures, which were recorded, tremendously helped as the lectures were often dense. I had to go back to watch the recordings to fill in any gaps and take notes on the slides. The format of discussion section was engaging as we discussed figures in relevant papers. Guest lecturers were also very helpful and interesting. Open-booked exams that were 90 minutes long also made exams slightly less stressful but they were still very long. Something that can be improved is posting slides ahead of time for more engagement during lectures and giving more feedback on Canvas through the exams or homework.
The virtual lectures were very similar to the in person experience, as was section.
It was very accessible in terms of being able to watch the recorded lecture and the content was very easily accessible. The TAs were fantastic in being accomodating for discussion sections
I actually think that the course worked pretty well all things considered.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Only if theyre very intested in the subject, but a good MCDB course
yes
I preferred MCDB 205 (cell bio) to this class.
Yes if they are interested in molecular biology (it is a really interesting class!), but it would probably be too much if you are taking 5 courses
Yes, this was my favorite biology course at Yale so far.

Since it is a major requirement, I guess but I discourage anyone from taking this with another upper level or difficult STEM course. There was so much material to memorize in addition to the weekly homework that it is definitely time-consuming (and a bit too much for a core course).

Definitely! The lectures were engaging and relevant. Especially in the Covid era, I think everyone should have a basic understanding of molecular biology. If nothing else, I leave this course feeling like a much better informed citizen.
Yes, this course fulfills MCDB requirements.

I would recommend this course if a student really wants to learn about DNA and RNA in depth (like the mechanisms, all of the proteins involved). However, just keep in mind this course can make you feel lost at times due to the enormous amount of detail and the lack of feedback or clarification.
I would recommend in an online format, because having recorded lectures and open book exams made it much more manageable than past years
Yes, if you need to take a biology course for your major
The professors really know what they're talking about, and its a great chance to get a cutting edge perspective on the field.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: discussion sections
live virtual lecture with weekly virtual sections for discussion of a relevant journal article
Weekly live virtual discussion sections.
Live virtual lecture and live virtual discussion section.
We had two live virtual lectures and one virtual discussion section per week.
Discussion section and texxtbook readings
Live section as well
recorded lecture plus live virtual discussion
There was also a live discussion section
The lectures were also available asynchronously, and the discussion sections were more of a virtual seminar/discussion format.
